periods.name: Divine Right
periods.desc:
Justified a king's power under the
idea that it was from God.

periods.name: Absolutist Rule
periods.what_changed:
This was in contrast to the fuedalist
systems where the monarch
essentially had to appeal to the
nobility.

periods.name: Parliamentary Rule
periods.what_changed:
This form of centralized government
existed before. However, the power
was, for the longest time, not in the
Parliament's hands.

periods.name: Social Contract
periods.desc:
The theory that monarchs' power
was derived from the masses
through a 'social contract.'
periods.what_changed:
This changed provided justification
to oppose the monarch, if they
broke the 'social contract.'

periods.name: Wealthy Influence
periods.desc:
Those who weren't nobility could
become wealthy, own land, and have
significant influence.
periods.what_changed:
This led to an increase in
class-enforcing laws, such as game
laws, or limits to who can wear purple.

periods.name: Classical Rediscovery
periods.desc:
The rediscovery of Greek and
Roman Philosophers' texts.
periods.what_changed:
Rediscoveries of texts created the
basis of Humanism.

periods.name: Copernican Model
periods.desc:
A heliocentric model of the universe,
as described by Copernicus.
periods.what_changed:
While this predated the Scientific
Revolution, its questioning of ancient
and pre-established authority is
considered the first step in modern
science.

periods.name: Inductive Reasoning
periods.desc:
A method by which someone could
observe truth.
periods.what_changed:
Believed to be developed by Francis
Bacon, the approach relied on trusting
nothing but what one could derive
from experiments.
periods.top: Hello Mr. Iannone! If you're seeing this, congratulations! You've found an Easter Egg!

periods.name: Deductive Reasoning
periods.desc:
A method by which someone could
derive truth.
periods.what_changed:
Believed to be developed by Ren√©
Descartes, the approach relied on
denying ancient and commonplace
knowledge, a radical idea for the time.
Became one pillar of modern science.

periods.name: Industrial Innovations
periods.desc:
The invention of revolutionary
machines, such as the Steam Engine.
periods.what_changed:
Allowed the process of
proletarianization and the later
consumerism by providing an
excess of goods.

periods.name: Religious Wars
periods.desc:
The series of wars mainly between
Catholic authority and various
Protestant groups.
periods.what_changed:
Those who opposed the Church
not only did so, but also were
effective.

periods.name: Puritan Takeover
periods.desc:
When England became a Puritan
Republic.
periods.what_changed:
This control was very tight, enforcing
strict Calvinist standards. Its
impopularity helped fortify
England's Parliamentary system.

periods.name: Austrian Succession
periods.desc:
Prussia's successful invasion of
Austria. A prime example of England
& France's rivalry.

periods.name: Seven Years' War
periods.desc:
The war which redirected most
countries away form colonialism.
periods.what_changed:
Led to England being the 'winner' of
the colony rivalries.

periods.name: Midieval Art
periods.desc: Art as it was from the Middle Ages.

periods.name: Renaissance Art
periods.desc:
Filled with geometry, perspective,
shadows, and 'perfect' humans.
periods.what_changed:
The most noticable change was its
depiction of people; with perfect
symmetry and form. This was
coupled with perspective.

periods.name: Baroque Art
periods.desc:
Filled with drama, less realism, and
more intense lighting.
periods.what_changed:
The paintings focused more
on the state and religion, not
dissimilar to propaganda.

periods.name: Written Word
periods.desc:
The rise of accessible Print Culture
began in the late 16th century.
periods.what_changed:
In contrast to before, texts were
affordable, and literacy rates in turn
increased.

periods.name: Catholic Supremacy
periods.desc:
Religion as it was from the
Middle Ages.

periods.name: Protestantism
periods.desc: New Ideas about theology
periods.what_changed:
People began to interpret doctrine
for themselves. Before, questioning
the church and its theology was
unthinkable.

periods.name: Edict of Nantes
periods.desc:
Secular tolerance over religion,
within France.
periods.what_changed:
This was the first of its kind; most
all countries would enforce the
ruler's religion of choice. It set a
model that would eventually be
followed.

periods.name: Edict of Fontainebleau
periods.what_changed:
This was a prime example of the
states' expanding power; Louis XIV
wanted no heretics, and adherence
for all.

periods.name: Treaty of Westphalia
periods.desc:
Ended the Thirty Years' War,
among others.
periods.what_changed:
Countries began to focus on power
and centralization over religion about
when this treaty was signed.

periods.name: Peace of Paris
periods.desc: Ended the Seven Years' War.
periods.what_changed:
Countries began to focus on
mercantilist and economic goals
instead of power and succession
around this time.
